text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits new IRM 4.23.26, Employment Tax, Campus Employment Tax Non-Filer Program.
This IRM incorporates IRM 4.19.15.43, Liability Determination, Discretionary Programs, Campus Employment Tax Non-Filer Program, which will be obsoleted concurrently with the publication of this
Signiﬁcant changes to this IRM are in the table below.

EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This material supersedes IRM 4.19.15.43 dated January 1, 2020. The following IRM Procedural Updates (IPUs) have been incorporated into this IRM: 20U0580 and 20U0794.
This IRM is intended for use by SB/SE Campus Examination Operations.

Campus Employment Tax Non-Filer Program 4.23.26 page 1
and (

) Purpose : This IRM provides procedural guidance for Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Campus Examination operation employees completing ployment Tax Non-Filer (ETNF) examinations. It provides instruction to help examiners accurately prepare Substitute for Return (SFR) employment tax returns and to ensure employers are in full compliance with all tax laws and regulation with regards to: ﬁling compliance, making timely payments, and claiming valid credits. (
) Audience : IRS employees who are responsible for completing ETNF examina- tions in SB/SE Campus Exam (
) Policy Owner : Director, Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE), Headquarters Examination - Field and Campus Policy (
) Program Owner : Program Manager, Campus Examination and Field Support (
) Program Goals : The program goals are to ensure all employers are in compli- ance with ﬁling their employment tax returns and to educate the taxpayer about their legal obligations and rights. (
) The ETNF program is worked by Cincinnati campus. The Audit Information Management System (AIMS) will show Primary Business Code (PBC)
, Project Code (PC)
Note: Cincinnati campus does not work PBC
) SB/SE Employment Tax Headquarters has primary responsibility for workload selection and delivery. (
) Tax examiners will resolve any employment tax issue that comes up during examination. (

) The Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) imposes a tax on both employers and employees. The amount of the tax is based on the amount of wages paid with respect to employment. For more information on what wages are subject to FICA tax, see the chart, Special Rules for Various Types of Services and Payments, in Section
of Pub

, (Circular E), Employer’s Tax Guide. FICA tax is composed of: • Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance, commonly referred to as Social Security tax, • Hospital insurance (Medicare) tax, and • Additional Medicare Tax. (

) Title IX of the Social Security Act established the unemployment insurance system. The Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) was designed to encourage states to enact unemployment insurance plans. This would allow states to provide beneﬁts to workers during periods of temporary unemploy- ment. To involve the states, Congress took the following actions: • Established the federal unemployment tax rate and • Allowed a limited credit against the federal tax to an employer if the state law meets certain federal requirements and the state certiﬁes that the credit is allowable. Employment Tax Non-Filer Program
page
Purpose : This IRM provides procedural guidance for Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Campus Examination operation employees completing Em
ployment Tax Non

Filer (ETNF) examinations. It provides instruction to help examiners accurately prepare Substitute for Return (SFR) employment tax returns and to ensure employers are in full compliance with all tax laws and regulation with regards to: ﬁling compliance, making timely payments, and claiming valid credits.
Note: Cincinnati campus does not work PBC
) SB/SE Employment Tax Headquarters has primary responsibility for workload selection and delivery. (
) Tax examiners will resolve any employment tax issue that comes up during examination. (

) The Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) imposes a tax on both employers and employees. The amount of the tax is based on the amount wages paid with respect to employment. For more information on what wages are subject to FICA tax, see the chart, Special Rules for Various Types of Services and Payments, in Section
of Pub

, (Circular E), Employer’s Guide. FICA tax is composed of: • Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance, commonly referred to as Social Security tax, • Hospital insurance (Medicare) tax, and • Additional Medicare Tax. (

) Title IX of the Social Security Act established the unemployment insurance system. The Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) was designed to encourage states to enact unemployment insurance plans. This would allow states to provide beneﬁts to workers during periods of temporary unemploy- ment. To involve the states, Congress took the following actions: • Established the federal unemployment tax rate and • Allowed a limited credit against the federal tax to an employer if the state law meets certain federal requirements and the state certiﬁes the credit is allowable.
Note: Cincinnati campus does not work PBC 212.

Established the federal unemployment tax rate and Allowed a limited credit against the federal tax to an employer if the state law meets certain federal requirements and the state certiﬁes that the credit is allowable.

) The federal portion of the tax is used to administer both the federal and state programs. Taxes collected by the states are usually paid as unemployment beneﬁts. Generally, no part of the state unemployment tax is withheld from employee wages. (
) Employment Tax Forms include: • Form
, Employer’s QUARTERLY Federal Tax Return, • Form
, Employer’s Annual Tax Return for Agricultural Employees, • Form
, Employer’s ANNUAL Federal Tax Return, • Form
, Annual Return of Withheld Federal Income Tax, • Form
, Employer’s Annual Federal Unemployment Tax Return, • Form
, and Schedule H , Household Employment Taxes. (
) Employment tax returns do not follow statutory notice of deﬁciency procedures. (

) IRS has the authority to prepare tax returns for any person or business that fails to submit a tax return required by law or regulation at the time prescribed, or makes (willfully or otherwise), a false, or fraudulent tax return. (
) Employment Tax provisions are found at Internal Revenue Code Subtitle C: • IRC
through
addresses the Federal Insurance Contributions Act. • IRC

addresses the Federal Income Tax Withholding (FITW). Note: The ETNF program does not pursue tax pertaining to the Railroad Retire-

Note: The ETNF program does not pursue tax pertaining to the Railroad Retire- ment Tax Act or Railroad Unemployment Repayment Tax.
) The Director, Small Business/Self Employed (SBSE), Headquarters Examina- tion, Field & Campus Policy, is responsible for the ETNF program. (

) Management officials are responsible for providing internal controls related to program processes and activities. They are also responsible for ensuring in- structions are communicated to and carried out by the proper employees. (
) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accor- dance with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, see the Tax- payer Bill of Rights . (

) The following reviews are used to evaluate the ETNF program: • Campus program reviews are conducted to ensure case actions are in accordance with IRM procedures. • Examination quality reviews are conducted using IRM
, Quality Assurance - Embedded Quality (EQ) Program for Accounts Manage-
The Director, Small Business/Self Employed (SBSE), Headquarters Examina- tion, Field & Campus Policy, is responsible for the ETNF program.
Campus program reviews are conducted to ensure case actions are in accordance with IRM procedures. Examination quality reviews are conducted using IRM
, Quality Assurance - Embedded Quality (EQ) Program for Accounts Manage-

Reports described in IRM

, AIMS Procedures and Processing, Reports, are used to monitor in-process cases. AIMS Centralized Information System reports are used by Headquarters Policy to review closure statistics and determine the effectiveness of program. Embedded Quality Review System Reports, are used by program analysts to identify error trends. National Quality Review System Reports, are used by managers to identify error trends.

is limited to two attempts. Note: If a letter is sent in reply to taxpayer correspondence, the letter and all letter attachments must identify the originating tax examiner to provide information for any subsequent contact. (

) Attempt to contact the taxpayer or POA by telephone when the information provided is insufficient. Explain why the information sent was insufficient and what is still needed. Document the call in case history and include the date, time, and outcome of the phone call. If the taxpayer can e-fax the missing in- formation, suspend the case for

business days. If the call attempt was unsuccessful or the taxpayer can’t e-fax the missing information, document the case history. Note: The examiner will advise the taxpayer of the deadline to submit a request an IRS appeals hearing in all contacts to ensure the taxpayer’s right to an appeals hearing is protected. See IRM
, Evaluating Taxpayer Responses, for additional information. (

If And Then The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 and states return was ﬁled, No tax return or supporting documents are included, Research account for ﬁled returns, if unable to locate, send a quick note. Note: If a letter from a taxpayer was received after the initial contact, Letter 4107, then a copy of the quick note should be sent with the second contact (See IRM 4.23.26.4, Second Contacts). The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 and states returns were ﬁled under another Employer Identiﬁcation Number (EIN), Research of IDRS command codes veriﬁes this information is correct, Close the case “No Change” and issue Letter 4109 to the taxpayer. The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 and states returns were ﬁled under another EIN, Research of IDRS command codes does not verify returns were ﬁled or additional informa- tion is needed to resolve the discrepancy, Send a quick note to the taxpayer with copies of IRPTR prints. Note: If a letter from a taxpayer was received after the initial contact, Letter 4107, then a copy of the quick note should be sent with the second contact. The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 with copy of return, Research of IDRS command codes indicates a Transaction Code (TC) 290 posted with tax, wages, and federal income tax withholding, Close the case “No Change with Adjustment” and issue Letter 4110, No Change Letter When Taxpayer Provides Missing Em- ployment Tax Returns, to the taxpayer. The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 with copy of return, Return is missing a signature, Attempt a phone call for the missing signature. If unable to reach the taxpayer by phone, send a quick note requesting signature. page 6 4.23 Employment Tax
Research of IDRS command codes veriﬁes this information is correct,
The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 and states returns were ﬁled under another Employer Identiﬁcation Number (EIN),

If And Then The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 with the signed return(s) under examina- tion, The return(s) match the informa- tion on ﬁle or research of the IDRS command codes show return(s) were received and match the information on ﬁle, Note: Correspondence Imaging System (CIS) images or BRTVU prints can be used as copies of return(s) to close an ex- amination as long as the wages match or are higher than reported. Close the case “Agreed” and issue Letter 4110 to the taxpayer. Note: If a TC 976 is on TXMOD without a TC 290, an -A freeze will post on TXMOD. If the case is being closed, input Priority Code “1” on Form 5344 to prevent the closure from unposting. The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 with signed returns under examination, The returns only verify a portion of the information on ﬁle, Accept ﬁled returns and input partial assessment of reported wages. Send a quick note, a revised report pursuing unre- ported wages, and sanitized copies of IRPTR. See IRM 4.23.26.13, Partials. Note: If returns were in response to Letter 4107, also send Letter 4108. The taxpayer replies to Letter 4108 with a signed copy of Form 2504, Agreement to Assessment and Collection of Additional Tax and Acceptance of Over assess- ment, N/A Close the case “Agreed.” The taxpayer replies that the business has been sold, N/A Send a quick note requesting the bill of sale or other documents to verify the sale of the business. The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 stating they had no employees during the examination period(s), N/A Refer case to Field Employment Tax. See IRM 4.19.13.15.1 . The taxpayer replies with Schedule H, N/A Close the case “No Change” and send Schedule H to Receipt and Control for processing. Campus Employment Tax Non-Filer Program 4.23.26 page
Campus Employment Tax Non-Filer Program

If And Then The taxpayer replies to Letter 4107 or Letter 4108 stating they are a church, There is no indication of the church being exempt, Send a quick note to the taxpayer. Note: If the church has only one employee who is the minister and they ﬁled self- employment tax on their personal tax return, then the church does not have to ﬁle a return. The taxpayer replies with Form 940, And is taking the state credit, but no Form 940-B was submitted, Send a quick note. See IRM 4.23.26.9, FUTA Certiﬁcation. page 8 4.23 Employment Tax

) The SFR program was developed to contact taxpayers who have not ﬁled tax returns voluntarily and for whom income information is available to substantiate a signiﬁcant tax liability. IRC
(b) grants the IRS the authority to create a tax return for the taxpayer if the taxpayer fails to ﬁle the return by the time scribed or ﬁles a false or fraudulent return. (
) IRC
(b) provides that a tax return is good and sufficient for all legal purposes. However, the
(b) return is not treated as a tax return ﬁled by the taxpayer. Form
-A, IRC Section
(b) Certiﬁcation for Employment Tax Returns is part of the SFR Employment Tax case ﬁle to establish that IRC
(b) criteria are met in order that the Failure to Pay (FTP) penalty under IRC
) will be sustained in court. Be aware of the following: • IRC
(b) tax return does not start the statute of limitations on an sessment. • IRC
(b) tax return does not stop the FTP penalty. • Form
-A is an “internal use only” form and should not be sent to the taxpayer. • Form
-A does not need to be completed when a case is closed “No Change” or a delinquent return was received. (

) Whenever the examiner revises a report of proposed adjustments that increases the total tax liability of the taxpayer (without regard to whether or the revised report is reissued to the taxpayer), a recertiﬁcation is required on another Form
-A dated on or after the date of the revised report. (
) If the report of proposed adjustments involves more than one tax period, a separate Form
-A for each tax period is created and attached to a copy of the report. (

, Processing When Deﬁciency Procedures Do Not Apply. (

page

The SFR program was developed to contact taxpayers who have not ﬁled tax returns voluntarily and for whom income information is available to substantiate a signiﬁcant tax liability. IRC 6020(b) grants the IRS the authority to create a tax return for the taxpayer if the taxpayer fails to ﬁle the return by the time pre- scribed or ﬁles a false or fraudulent return.

IRC 6020(b) provides that a tax return is good and sufficient for all legal purposes. However, the 6020(b) return is not treated as a tax return ﬁled by the taxpayer. Form 13496-A, IRC Section 6020(b) Certiﬁcation for Employment Tax Returns is part of the SFR Employment Tax case ﬁle to establish that IRC 6020(b) criteria are met in order that the Failure to Pay (FTP) penalty under IRC 6651(a)(2) will be sustained in court. Be aware of the following:
IRC
(b) tax return does not start the statute of limitations on an as- sessment. IRC
(b) tax return does not stop the FTP penalty. Form
-A is an “internal use only” form and should not be sent to the taxpayer. Form
-A does not need to be completed when a case is closed “No Change” or a delinquent return was received.
If the report of proposed adjustments involves more than one tax period, a separate Form 13496-A for each tax period is created and attached to a copy
Research IDRS for a current address as per IRM 4.19.13.14. Clearly document the case history with the actions taken and research.

If And Then The second contact has not been sent, Research indicates there is a more current address, Send undeliverable Letter 4107, Letter 4108 with attach- ments and Form 8822-B to the more current address. Allow 30 days for response and purge after 45 days.
If taxpayers do not respond to the exam, close case default after Day

) Follow the procedures below to manually assess the penalty:

If Then The FTD penalty should be assessed at case closing 1. Calculate TC 180 for 10 percent of the TC 300 amount minus total timely payments to be input on Form 5344. 2. At closing input an IDRS monitoring control on TXMOD using the “Control Base Actions” IAT-GII tool and follow up after 46 days. 3. If the taxpayer does not pay ditional TC 180 is necessary. 4. Total all payments made TC 300 amount. 5. Multiply the amount in Step 4 by 5 percent. 6. Input the amount from Step 5 as the TC 180 amount to assess the tiered penalty. Use Hold Code “0” and Penalty Reason Code “011.” The adjustment will be a non-source document. Close the monitoring control base. Note: TC 290/291 may affect the penalty calculation. Be sure to add or subtract adjustments from TC 290/291. The TC 300 amount is full paid Close the monitoring control base and do not assess the additional 5 percent penalty. The FTD penalty should not be assessed at closing Input a TC 180 for zero on Form 5344. 4.23 Employment Tax #### ## ## #

If Then The FTD penalty needs to be abated in full or part due to calcu- lation error Input a TC 181 for the appropri- ate amount, use Penalty Reason Code “045.” Note: If all or part of the origi- nally assessed TC 180 should be abated, also check to see if TC 160 was correctly calculated. The FTF penalty rate to be assessed at closure is 22.5 percent. Follow the procedures below:
4.23.26.8.2(01-26-2022) Failure to File Penalty (TC 160)

IF THEN The FTF penalty should be assessed at case closing Calculate TC 160 for 22.5 percent of the TC 300 amount minus total timely payments to be input on Form 5344 The FTF penalty should not be assessed at closing Input a TC 160 for zero on Form 5344. The FTF penalty needs to be abated in full or part due to calcu- lation error Input a TC 161 for the appropri- ate amount, use Penalty Reason Code “045.”
) The initial request for relief may occur either during or after an examination. (
) Refer to IRM
, Criteria for Relief from Penalties, as a resource guide for the non-assertion of penalties due to Reasonable Cause (RC). (
) If the taxpayer is entitled to penalty relief, complete RC penalty lead sheet and document workpapers that reasonable cause was considered, and how rea- sonable cause was established. (
) If the taxpayer is not entitled to penalty relief, complete RC penalty lead sheet and document workpapers that reasonable cause was considered and why reasonable cause does not apply. (

) The Federal Unemployment Tax Act provides for cooperation between the federal and state governments in the establishment and administration of un- employment insurance programs. Under this dual system, the employer is subject to a payroll tax levied by the federal and state governments. (
) There are currently
participating state level entities, which include the
states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.
Refer to IRM 20.1.1.3, Criteria for Relief from Penalties, as a resource guide for the non-assertion of penalties due to Reasonable Cause (RC).
There are currently 53 participating state level entities, which include the 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

, General IDTVA Letter Procedures. Continue processing the frivolous ﬁling following normal proce- dures.

) If the taxpayer provides a phone number, the examiner must make one phone call to secure missing information or clarify an unresolved issue related to the reconsideration request before disallowing in full or in part due to lack of infor- mation. (

) The examiner must review the case ﬁle before calling the taxpayer so they can advise the taxpayer of all return issues and all documentation needed. Examiners will document the workpapers with the taxpayer’s phone number, date and time of contact. See IRM
, Telephone Contact. (
) If the taxpayer submits additional information that would result in accepting the returns as ﬁled, check that the returns are signed and report all wages and withholding.
If the taxpayer submits the same information or still does not send what is required, send Letter 916C. Input TC 290 for zero.
Limitations (

) The Internal Revenue Code provides that the IRS will assess tax, make refunds or credits, and collect taxes within speciﬁc time limits. These limits known as the Statutes of Limitations. Examiners must be aware of these tions and the necessary steps required to be taken when these limitations encountered. a. Most of the time, the reconsideration request is for a tax decrease. The examiner may be making adjustments resulting in an overpayment and must determine if the taxpayer is entitled to receive a refund of the payment based on the Refund Statute Expiration Date (RSED). Generally, a claim for refund must be ﬁled within three years from the date the original return was ﬁled or two years from the date the tax paid, whichever is later. b. There may be multiple RSEDs that apply to a taxpayer’s situation. c. IRC
(c)states that employment tax returns reporting FICA tax or FITW for any period ending with or within a calendar year ﬁled before April
of the succeeding calendar year are considered ﬁled on April of that succeeding calendar year. d. IRC
(c) states that FICA tax or FITW paid during any period ending with or within a calendar year before April
of the succeeding calendar year is considered paid on April
of that succeeding calendar year. e. If no return was ﬁled, the claim may be allowed if ﬁled within
years from the date of payment(s). See IRM
, Claims for Credit Refund – General Time Period for Submitting a Claim, for guidance. f. A claim or amended return is timely if received or postmarked within
years of the received date of the original return or within two years of date the tax is paid. See IRM
, Claims for Credit or Refund General Time Period for Submitting a Claim and IRM
, Basic Guide for Processing Cases with Statute of Limitations Issues, for guidance. (

) If an adjustment is made to a taxpayer’s account and the result is an overpay- ment that cannot be refunded due to the RSED, the examiner must notify taxpayer that an adjustment was made to the account, but due to the RSED the overpayment will not be refunded. Use Letter
C or Letter
C with appropriate explanation. See IRM
, Abatement Authority. Return (
) Original returns claiming a refund ﬁled by a taxpayer are valid claims. (
) Sending the notice of claim disallowance by registered or certiﬁed mail sets beginning of the taxpayer’s two-year period of limitations to ﬁle a refund suit under IRC
) This two-year period of limitations only applies when the taxpayer ﬁles a valid claim. The period of limitations under IRC
) applies when the taxpayer submits a valid claim on the original return . (
) If the adjustments to tax or credits shown on a claim for refund or request abatement have been posted to Master File, it is no longer a claim for refund or request for abatement.

) When the taxpayer ﬁles a valid claim, but the examiner needs additional infor- mation to substantiate it, and the taxpayer fails to provide it, send the notice claim disallowance. This will start the two-year refund suit period under IRC
) period. (

) If the claim is defective or IRS can’t determine the merits of the claim, and taxpayer does not respond to a request for the information needed to validate the claim, the taxpayer has no basis for ﬁling a refund suit. (

) Additional information provided after the RSED can be considered if ﬁnal action has not been taken on the claim. However, information provided after the RSED cannot vary the facts or legal basis of a claim so as to constitute, effect, a new claim. IRS may waive the requirement in its regulations as to the form and contents of a claim, but it cannot waive the requirement under IRC
that a claim be submitted timely. (

) If a taxpayer submits a reconsideration request for reversal of an audit assess- ment or reversal of credits disallowed on the original return and a formal disallowance letter has not been sent, then the RSED is still open. See IRM
, Reconsideration after the RSED, where Notice of Claim Disal- lowance not Sent, for additional information and instruction on how to input adjustment when the RSED is expired.
